@shahanSean Hopefully my "Rome" class will at least get some students to realize that 1) most people were (legally) *not* Romans within the boundaries of the empire and 2) "Roman" was a (near) universal legal status granted only in 212 CE; hence we have a lot of non-Roman "Romans"

@shahanSean I deal w/ the issue of "who is Roman" in a number of classes (my Greek history class emphasizes the use of the term "Roman" in the eastern Med) and even with that focus, the alignment of "Roman" = "Rome" (city) and "western Europe" only is  *so* strong.
But it is a price, and we need to remember that we agreed to these terrible terms.

I say these things, however, so that we are aware of the calculations that we are making.  We are making the calculation that the ongoing deaths and slaughter in Ukraine -- and whatever horrible peace might come from it -- is the lesser price to pay.

These tweets are not to point fingers and say "well, we should have done x".  From what I could tell, the available options then (and now) were all terrible and (like most options) had no guarantee of success.

During the Cold War, we "sacrificed" places like Hungary and Czechoslovakia to external oppression because we didn't want a hot war.  In effect, we condemned generations to live in a system that we knew was 1) oppressive and 2) not what they wanted.

One thing on my mind is how much death the US is willing to know about & absorb, even when that death occurs in "places where it shouldn't" (re: Europe).  The US didn't get involved in WWII until Japan bombed Pearl Harbor.  Europe had been overrun & we went 🤷🏽‍♀️

@Lady_Historian And honestly, there is just not enough time in the day (semester) for me to provide detailed comments for all the work (I have a 4/4).  There just isn't and most of them don't have the time themselves to take it all in.

@Lady_Historian This semester, I am having students submit a full first draft, then do in-class peer-review sessions, and submit their revisions a week later.  I want them to get used to relying on themselves and each other for feedback rather than just a single authority (me).

@Lady_Historian Last semester, I made students send me full & complete outlines (I had step-by-step instructions) for comments, then they submitted final papers.  I graded each portion 50%-50% with "100" = "did the assignment", "75" = "I got something" and "50" = "failed to follow instructions."

I have been telling my students to not underestimate the scale of deaths the Russian state will be able to absorb.  I should also start telling them not to underestimate the scale of deaths --and the eventual terms of peace-- that we in the West will be able to absorb.

@Notorious_RSG That pathway really does set up "history" as "not worthy," which must be the most demoralizing thing for historians

@Notorious_RSG Now, in other parts of the world, "History" is an assigned course of study, as in "You were not successful enough on the national exam; the only degrees open to you are History and other Liberal Arts." I know this is the case for a number of MENA countries.

@Notorious_RSG I do always remind myself that if history (and really, everything else) was so "useless" in America & Europe, people with *any* access to money wouldn't spend thousands on it for their own children in terms of private school, "enrichment" programs, summer camps, etc.

@Notorious_RSG And when you combine that sort of scarcity thinking with demographic changes in higher ed (can't keep out the women & non-whites anymore) you get a resurgence of ideas such as "history is just for elite men to do on weekends, not a fundamental part of universal education"

@Notorious_RSG To be a little more fair & historically minded), the postwar (is it now "interwar"?) notion of "America is #1" combined with the realization that we actually are *not #1* produced a lot of "après moi, le deluge" thinking. It's our lot now to be smack in the middle of it.

@Notorious_RSG I think it's easy to blame the STEM chasers out there,  folks I know in STEM say STEM is pretty fucking bleak ("Do you study cancer? Is it a common cancer? If "no" to 1 and/or 2, no money for you").  I think the "college::path2$uce$$" idea is the real smoking gun.

@NaomiRendina This is a reason why I assign an *entire* book (along with most of 2 other books plus articles) for my first-year "Intro to the Liberal Arts" course.  I want to make sure that at least 20-25 of them will not be able to say this.

"We live in a circle of cannons pointed at us, and it constricts itself hour by hour."

One thing I did not expect to come up in class:  Texas' new mandate that all K-12 educators narc on trans kids.  My first class did not believe me, then immediately started to look it up.  They were horrified.

It really is a shock to the system when the world seems to change overnight; it is perhaps more shocking when you start to realize all of the things that have been swirling around long before you were born.

I think that aspect of "dusty history" (my words) now having real teeth and staying power is v. jarring to a number of them.  One student had a hard time believing that Russia is actually a US ally and has been since 1991.
Both groups of students are now confronting a history whose various framings (Cold War, NATO, post-Soviet Europe, communism vs. fascism) are begin called upon in very real & tangible ways.
In both classes, we talked about how things are framed and why.  I emphasize this part of history all the time, but I think today's events drove that point home in a very visceral way.
We also went over the Capitularies (https://t.co/TJj55BQElg) and emphasized how this text enshrines Frankish control as *the* control and Christianity as *the* moral paradigm.

For the second class, we discussed how Saxon actions were framed by the Carolingians as "rebellion", therefore making them (Saxons) liable for conquest.  We also touched upon how other Carolingians allied with the Saxons against Charles Martel & Pippin.

We highlighted the ways in which Saxons paid large tribute to Merovingian and Carolingian Franks, but then, after about 80+ years of that, decided to take advantage of regime change (RIP Pippin of Herstal) and assert their independence.

For my first class, we started with a rapid overview of the Soviet Union, WWII, NATO, and Ukraine c. 2005 - today, then asked how this Russia-Ukraine tug over sovereignty helps us understand the Carolingian - Saxon fight over the same thing.
Today, I taught the Carolingian-Saxon wars in light of current events.🧵

And Gigi's takedown of Liane (and her world) is absolute ice.  You can just see how it cuts Gaston. https://t.co/WJnOjyIGUf

In short, "Gigi" is more profound than I thought.  Focusing *just* on the parts that make us queasy causes us to overlook the entire premise.  Trying to get rid of those parts gives us a false sense of superiority, & causes us to overlook the areas where our worlds overlap.

In this world, they are not *supposed* to marry.  They are also not supposed to be married *and* in love.  Instead, it's the thrill of the chase and the fine arts of trading up that are held in high regard for each of them.  Both Gigi & Gaston loudly ask "why is that?"

It is interesting that "Gigi" directly comments on these things and still works within the boundaries of fin-de-scècle France.  Yes, she and Gaston marry (the film is upfront about the 2 options available to women) but by marrying, the two rebuff social & class expectations.

We have to remember that, for all of the comments such as "well, 'Gigi' was *then*", our societies *still* operate on those levels in a number of ways.  If you're queasy about "Gigi", are you also queasy about capitalism? Labor exploitation? Sex dynamics? Maybe.  Maybe not.
I don't think that message should get scrubbed out of the story.  That message --and the way it still leaves people feeling empty inside -- *is* the story of Gigi.

At least Gigi's family (and everyone around them) is frank about what's going on.  Aunt Alicia is not joking when she says "You do this to eat & live, and learning how to get the most bang for your buck takes skill."

Yet at the end of "My Fair Lady" we are supposed to see Henry and Eliza as some sort of love story, even though he is "training" her to be a "lady" just as rigorously (and with extra classism & eugenics thrown in) as Gigi's family, but since it's for "science" it's cool.

In contrast, Shaw's play ends with Eliza straight up leaving Henry Higgins after she tells him that she has a level of worth he will never see.  The "Bring me my slippers" line is there to demonstrate that he remains clueless as ever despite it all.

It's a queasiness that does not come through in "My Fair Lady" despite the fact that Henry Higgins is just straight-up *awful* to Eliza in the name of "science".  At the end of MFL, he gets to continue being awful ("Bring me my slippers") even *after* Eliza said she was done.

That's what I find fascinating about this film.  Because everything is so candy-colored and bright and *hon hon hon* "fwench" (WTF is up with Gigi's "fwench" singing?), we get a little queasy when we finally realize *what* this world actually is.  That queasiness is key.

The weird irony is that if "Gigi" was done as a drama instead of a (musical) comedy, we would probably be okay with things.  The tension between Gigi & her family (and arguably, between Gigi & the world) would read as sympathetic.  But we would not understand the world itself.

Gigi knows that optics is the name of the game, and she hates it.  She also seems to do a pretty good job of stating what her boundaries are, despite the fact that everyone else is telling her to shut up.  Somehow, that bit is lost in reviews/recaps: https://t.co/7y4qPXQVC0

On the one ✋🏽, I understand the desire to make "Gigi" less "creepy".  On the other 🤚🏽, if we decide that what is needed is to (slightly) age up the character and make Mamita a little warier, then our issue isn't *really* with sex-for-money, just optics.  And that's creepier.

And not providing medical care to those who lose a baby in utero or who gestate an abnormal fetus is barbaric and deadly.

Making someone carry a pregnancy that they do not want to term is barbaric.  Making someone give birth to a baby that they do not want is barbaric.  Making someone care for a child that they do not want or cannot care for is barbaric and child abuse.

I can't 🤬 believe medical decisions for a population writ-large are being made by people *without* medical training and *without* consulting the patients to whom such decisions will apply. I just 🤬 CANT.

And for the love of Tenure, don't put the onus on them to "educate" or "reach out" to the person who made them feel that way with their actions, comments, or deeds.  Just don't.  That system of making the aggrieved bear the responsibility is victim-blaming.

It is our job as teachers and mentors to acknowledge what they are feeling and to center the moment on them, not us, not our institution, or anything else.  It is the acknowledgment of being seen and heard that they seek, not the HR line about "X place is welcoming."

Fellow Profs: When a student comes to tell you about "an incident" (racist/sexist/classist/etc.,) that happened to them, the correct response is: "I am so sorry that this happened to you, that it affected you, & that it is causing you to feel this way. That is a lot to bear."

And, of course, this framework applies to "North Africa" as well; once we break that down & recognize the different "North Africas" that existed, I suspect we will not paint that region's history with the same old broad brush.

I think once we start with the big guns, some of the smaller pieces & remains will start making a lot more sense. I also suspect that instead of seeing "al-Andalus" & "Spain" as "appendages" of "Medieval Europe" & "the Muslim West," we'll see just how integrated they were.

This approach might be an easy thing to do with individuals but I also think we need to apply this principle to large categories such as "al-Andalus", "Muslim," "Christian", "Jew", "Spain" and crack them open in order to see the variety within each one over space & time.

What happened in one place (or in one text) can't be translated to another region and left as a placeholder; it can be compared to a similar situation or event, but there cannot be a clear 1:1 substitution.

It's taken 20 years but I think I finally understand the contours of medieval al-Andalus & the necessary parameters for historical investigation: Our categories (Muslim, caliph, Arab, Mozárabe) are relative absolutes that must be interrogated at every turn, not left to rest. 🤔
If the mulūk al-Tawā'if had to deal w/an expansionist Léon-Castile or Aragon any sooner, the whole thing would have sunk long before the Almoravids crossed the High Atlas.

I don't think I fully realized how much of a hot mess the first Tawa'if period (1009-1110) was until I read the Tarikh mulūk al-Tawā'if.  Starting to suspect only reason why al-Andalus survived that period was due to the fact that Alfonso VI was busy taking out his brothers.

Someday, someone is going to write a doctor's thesis on all this.  And not long after that, someone else might throw a "Christmas Party" in the way that folks now throw a Saturnalia. That should be a trip. (H/T @ClubOBERON & @BostonCircus for their super fun Saturnalia.)

But in acquiescing to someone else's belief in Santa et al., I am still participating in a hybrid version of a religio-cultural holiday, in much the same way, perhaps, as I do when I hand out candy at Halloween.

To be clear, I'll won't tell a kid who believes in Santa/Tooth Fairy/Easter Bunny/Krampus that they're wrong; that's mean.  I just don't think I would put my (hypothetical) kids through the same fiction.

But those same kids then grow up & do the same thing to their kids.  Why not just tell them to truth?  The pull of hybridity, I think, is strong enough that it influences folks to continue the practice, such as folks like my partner who grew up an atheist.

My boo & I are split on this.  He doesn't see an issue with Santa & kids; I think it's lying, like the Easter Bunny or Tooth Fairy.  At some point, the kid learns that all of those things are just their parents.

I expect that because I changed confessionally, that I will no longer do/participate in things. Christmas (& Easter) come to mind.  Easter is easier to dodge but Christmas is stickier.  Santa-God is everywhere & we encourage kids to believe in him.

After some reflection, I am now thinking about hybridity in religious & cultural practices, specifically how practices continue after a confessional change. Perhaps what's eating me is the hybridity of Christmas & my uncertainty about where I (& others) stand in relation to it.
And to everyone else, a happy Chinese Food and a Movie Day.
To those who celebrate the holiday as the birth of their Lord & Savior, and to those who just celebrate without overthinking it, I wish you a merry Christmas.

Anyway, I'm a crank who is for gift-giving as a sign of love & friendship & as a means to start a new year, but weirded out that the religious reasons for the gift giving in the first place are pretty much swept under the rug & not critiqued by (Christian) society at large.

And don't get me started on the stories that try to bring Santa into the Nativity story, as though St. Nick is some dude who existed completely apart from Jesus and had to be "reminded" about the "reason for the season."

But since I no longer believe in a personal deity/deities, the whole gift-giving aspect of Christmas sits uncomfortably with me.  Why do we do this? And Santa? Why do we keep Santa? It's a weird thing to teach children.

Perhaps this tension is due to the fact that I no longer go to services; opening gifts after Midnight Mass did a good job in distracted me.  After all, I had done my bit; what's the harm in presents (and Santa) after communion?

As I become more atheistic, the tension between the practice of honoring a god who eschewed things of this world & preached the dangers of worldly possessions by buying gifts & participating in multi-day feasting is more visible to me now than it ever did when I was a believer.

@shahanSean @iandavidmorris @MTalatAhmed @binkle993 That's true; ijazahs have been historically granted to small children (sometimes by the * exceedingly* aged!) and not all studies/students received an ijaza. @iandavidmorris @MTalatAhmed @binkle993 That starts to change after the spread of madrasa system during 12th & 13th century. For the purposes of the al-Qarawiyyin discussion, the fact that al-Qarawiyyin (& al-Azhar, al-Qayrawan) is not a madrasa seems to be the most obvious refutation of the جامع=university argument.

@iandavidmorris @MTalatAhmed @binkle993 This type of educational structure is most clearly preserved in tabaqat (biographical dictionaries) and fihrist (indexes of teachers).  In the examples I look at (10-13th cent) people travel to study w/specific individuals, not at an institution.

@iandavidmorris @MTalatAhmed @binkle993 Education prior to the establishment of madrasas (so before late 12th century) was not based upon going to a place & completing a "course" of study, but individual study wherein one was granted an ijaza (license) to teach a specific transmission of a work (e.g. Hadith, legal tex)

@iandavidmorris @3saime @Ballandalus @binkle993 Another rando historian jumping in: when the term جامع shows up in medieval Arabic geographies (c. 870-1150) it usually denotes a congregational mosque where Friday prayers & the khutba are given.  There is no comment about education, ijaza, etc.  The same holds for Al-Azhar.

@iandavidmorris @blocck3 @Ballandalus @binkle993 My own research into Moroccan history c. 800-1470 has revealed v. little historical info about al-Qarawiyyin as an educational institution.  Its archives have not been formally studied & the institution itself was closed c. 1956 only reopened in 1988 as part of Fez's UNESCO bid.

Big H/T to Erin L. Jordan for her research on Jeanne and Marguerite of Flanders & Hainaut.  I'm sure it wasn't easy going through these documents, much less writing about the whole thing.

I'm going to argue that maybe we should judge the past.  Jeanne of Flanders' fight for her sister seems to indicate in some small way, not everyone was ok with child/minor sexual abuse & rape.  Even in the 13th century.

And as much as we historians try to dismiss such instances in the distant past, we are doing a grave disservice everytime we read about a Marguerite of Flanders & and tell our students & our colleagues "things were different then.  We can't judge the past."

Our constant refrain of "what were you wearing?" "Are you sure it was him?" "Why were you drunk?" "How can you not remember everything?" "Why did you stay in touch/date them/marry them?" is the proof of this long & robust tradition.

It is therefore not surprising that this issue is still not seen as problematic in contemporary society.  Girls (and boys) are still paying the terrible price for our continued "blessing" of the idea that it is ok for men to be sexually attracted to them & act on that desire.
Nowhere in historical discussion is the original issue--men being conditioned to  see children & minors as sexual partners--addressed.  It is just not even considered as something problematic.

Echos of this "consent" are still part & partial to our rape & sexual assault laws now.  If a teenager is past the age of consent & says "yes", it's all cool.  Even if a parent or guardian okay's a legal minor's marriage, that's also ok.

Only then was Jeanne legally armed to rescue her 10 year old sister.  Notice how sexual relations with a 10 year old was still okay; the legal issue was the fact that Marguerite married a family member.  Presumably, if Jeanne had OK'd the marriage, there would be no problem.

To do so, Jeanne had to argue that as her sister's guardian, she had not given permission for Marguerite's "marriage", therefore her sister had been abducted.  But for this to stick, Jeanne had to argue that the absence of papal forgiveness for consanguinity = proof of  abduction

As in so many cases of the routine abuse and assualt of women and girls, only Marguerite's sister, Jeanne, Countess of Flanders and Hainault, came to her aid.  Jeanne was 14.  She then spent a decade trying to get her sister's marriage annulled.
This is similar language used nowadays to discredit victims of sexual assault and rape, including an 11 year French old girl raped by a 28 year old man in 2017.https://t.co/CIiEAySl8b

This particular shudder brought on by reading about the marriage & subsequent "consummation" of 10 year old Marguerite of Flanders and Hainault on 1212 and how she was described as "more than willing". (Archives Nationales, Paris, J 540).

Things that should never be glossed over: the long-standing expectation placed on men to marry (and then subsequently rape) girls and young teenagers, & for everyone to just accept it as part & parcel of life.  We historians should be better about addressing this fact.

Things I think about: for the vast majority of Germans during the Nazi era, things really didn't "get bad" until 1945.  And a lot of that was because the war started to (literally) hit home. 

We are still in the early stages of our descent. And most of us won't even notice it.

"Granted, mentoring and management training may be on offer through a university or institute. But why take time from the lab to do it? Managerial skills aren’t how scientists get promoted — research is."
"That hostile environment is perpetuated by a focus on the science — and not on the people doing it."

So fight on. Raise hell. Break the law.  Resist with all your might. And know your enemy. Know what the stakes are, what and who you are up against, and what the outcomes might be. Only by knowing your enemy will you be prepared to fight. To resist. To tell others what happened.
That is but one more reason why it is going to take DECADES to recover from this. DECADES.

My friend and their partner are just two of the early leavers.  They read the writing on the wall long ago and left.  They are not the only ones in my circle who have talked about leaving the US.  They are not the only ones who are keeping their papers in order.

One of the signs of a civilizational decline is when those with means and resources flee. Not the rich; they always can move, but the upper middle and middle classes.  When they start going, and going in numbers, that's when you're slipping.

A good number of people called it.  They named it, they warned us, and a good number of us heard that call.  But they were (long) outmanoeuvred by those who worked tirelessly to discredit them and block them at every turn. Evil never sleeps and it has been working overtime.

For a of those who are horrified, who are wondering what the hell is going on, what you've been seeing these past few years is a live breakdown of a country, person by person, and institution by institution.  That is not an easy thing to fix, not an easy thing to recover from.
And that is a hard thing to look in the face and call it for what it is.
And as historians, we both know that it is very possible to not see that come to pass, and we know that it is likely that we won't see it, either.

So my friend and I are not being hyperbolic Debbie Downers when we think of the DECADES it will take to recover from the damages being done today.  If anything, we are being overly hopeful that we will both live long enough to see our country recover.

This is the most positive version I can think of because: 1) it has an terminus ad quem in the very near future; 2) follows the rules and norms of our democratic government, thereby allowing us to avoid political crisis; 3) does not involve war or a coup d'état.

And then we are going to need to Marshall Plan ourselves out of this epic hole for a decade, if not more, in order just to GET BACK to where we were at the end of 2016.  And let's be honest: we had some major issues in 2016 that needed attention.

The SOONEST we are getting out of this hell is if, by some insane stroke of luck combined with more work than we've done in generations, a Blue 🌊 sweeps in 2020 like an epic tsunami and utterly drowns the Republican party in Republican districts.

If he gets impeached (don't hold your breath), we have President Pence, who will be his own version of horribly bad and decidedly not good for many.  Just ask IN residents for what could happen.  Plus all the other appointments remain in tact.

*IF* there is a Blue 🌊 in November, Trump is still President.  He can still appoint people to the SC, to lower courts, and to other offices.  If he gets blocked by a newly blue Congress, he still has the Ex. & a very conservative SC.
And if you think it's bad now (AND IT IS! IT IS! THAT CAN'T BE SAID ENOUGH!) it will get a whole lot worse before it gets better.

Today I talked with an American friend who said that they do not envision themselves or their partner returning to the US for "several decades." That's how deep of a hole we're in after LESS THAN TWO YEARS.

And that belief is probably why I'm still in this game despite all the hell that it currently entails.

These are the thoughts that I have as I read the news, wonder what I could possibly do to stop it all, and deal with the difficulties of doing a History PhD & prepping for an academic career at the same time. Funny enough, I still believe that a Giver is a key part of society.

And when we do pass our memories, we will have to tell our Givers-in-training that sometimes, all the knowledge in the world does not stop evil. One has to be prepared for that, and one has to keep on remembering so that we don't forget what it was like before.

It means that we historians have to keep on doing our jobs as guardians and explorers of the past (teaching, writing, publishing, you name it) while preserving our own history for those future historians who will come.  And when the time comes, we will give them our memories.

That means we have to survive.  We have to outlive and outlast those who are currently in power.  It means we have to remember those who are trampled and keep their names and stories alive for the generations to come.

What we can do is remember.  We can remember what is happening.  We can read the reports that are being filed, the articles that are being published everywhere, and we can guard that information for the future.  We can keep that information for the day when it will be heard.

We are currently unable to stop what is happening right now in our country.  We can do small acts of heroism, but we cannot remove Gorsuch and replace him with Garland.  We can support the ACLU, but we can't revoke Sessions' orders of "no tolerance."

One had to carry the memory of the color red, the joys of sledding, and also the memories of death.  Of pain.  Of failure and dispair. One had to bear that weight so that the society would remember why it chose Sameness, and Release, and the Ceremony of Twelve.

Now I'm remembering the role of The Giver in that society and seeing, perhaps for the first time, what Lowry was getting at when folks said that The Giver was a hard role.  It was hard because one had to carry the memories of all the failures.

Lois Lowry's The Giver came out when I was a kid and I've always thought about that particular character as I've gone along my journey to become a historian.  I thought that my role as a historian was to be a part of a wise counsel to prevent past mistakes (the Santayana bit).
And this brings me back to the role of the historian and of History itself.

Of course, you might not see it when the end comes (hint: it's usually one of your guys who stops playing on your team that does it) but who thinks of that when you have the power? So long as you can do what you want, you're good. Who cares if folks think you're barbaric?

With that combination, you can withstand the nature of a democracy.  You can withstand people gathering in the street, and you can weather the press reporting on your deeds because you know no one internally can stop you.

And if you really want to remake the world, you need to remake the government. You don't just need to hold a House or Senate or the Presidency; you need a President to appoint Secretaries overseeing the physical state, you need a Congress to block, & a Court to rule in your favor

What our representatives do know --esp. Republican representatives--is that power is fleeting and if you want to stay in power, you need to take steps to ensure your power. You need to control the votes through redistricting & voter roles. You need to control court appointments.

And our representatives know that we know. They know about our calls, they see us in their halls, they hear about our strikes, our marches, and what we think about what the hell is going on.  They know, but they do not believe what we're saying is true.

And we knew about Trump.  We knew about the massive ideological shift within the Republican party.  We knew because we documented it.  We filmed it. We consumed it.  We knew.  And we are still here now, still consuming the information, still being told what is going on.

We know about the detention centers.  We know about ICE's crackdown.  We know about the selling out of a Supreme Court seat. We know this because word gets out.  It's published in the papers.  Folks draft lawsuits based on tips and calls, and the court proceedings are filed.

A refrain that's been playing since Nov 9, 2016 at least is that there is a lack of information; that folks "just don't know the truth" because we're all obsessed w/ surface stuff.  But any historian worth their salt knows that is never the case.  People know. Stuff gets out.

What we forget, and what we are dealing with RIGHT NOW, is that there are other arguments out there.  There are competing narratives, many of them using the same evidence that we historians dug up, that seem *just as real* as ours. And folks in power are using them w/aplomb.

This of course, assumes that folks are interested in listening to us.  It also assumes that folks are persuaded by  (our) evidence and (our) argument, and then make the (right) choice based on what we told them.

We historians, the thinking goes, are here to dispense historical memory to future generations in order to make sure that past horrors are not repeated.  We remember & we remind folks to stick to the straight & narrow or else, not unlike Jacob Marley/Ghost of Xmas Past.
I've also been thinking about that (often misunderstood) George Santayana bit about being doomed to repeat the past because of historical ignorance, and the social role of historians.

I've been thinking a lot History; how the discipline is structured, the debates about history from below, longue durée, and the focus on "surface" things such as constructing an understanding of the past largely based on the remnants of political and elite actors.

This does not bode well for the future of Academic Institutions, nor the profession as a whole.

As a grad student, I'm supposed to be worrying about the persuasiveness of my argument & the flow of my dissertation, not being blackballed

It is beyond distressing that fellow academics must be called upon to write to an institution defending the student & their teaching.
It is beyond distressing to read about a grad student being thrown under the bus by their institution b/c a 3rd party hated ed pedagogy.
And no locked Twitter account or tacit silence on the part of its employees or anyone else in the Academy can change that.
If institutions like @Penn et al., fear being called the Devil more than they fear doing good, then they have rightly earned the name.
No one wants to be called the Devil, not even the Devil himself. But the point of academia is to call a spade a spade, not pretend otherwise
With an environment like this, of course it makes even the most self-confident consider the Devil's bargain: Your soul for a job.
It now becomes "your fault", not the fault of an institution built on the idea that you should be lucky to be employed, that you get canned.
It make you, the one who is dedicating a life to understanding how things work & sharing that info w/others, "responsible" for the backlash.
And that's the insidious soft power that's at the heart of @upenn debacle: it makes you, the one who questions things for a living, guilty.

@MedievalND 5) Byzantine education indicates an continuity of the Classical philosophy traditions despite the laments about the "decline" of education.
@MedievalND 4) Evidence of this logical & philosophical training is found among other Byzantine scholars & theologians indicating its' place in pedagogy
@MedievalND 3) The use of Aristotelian logic was both functional & appropriately used: folks understood logic & argumentation; it was not "decorative".
@MedievalND 2) This logic was not confined to a certain discipline (e.g. Philosophy, History) but was an active tool employed for understanding faith.
@MedievalND It is the application of this logic is what is really worth study, since it shows us 1) Aristotelian logic was a part of 8th cent Byzantium.
@MedievalND Of course, all of this logic could (and were) used to argue *for* the use of icons, since if icons represent God & Saints then worship is OK
@MedievalND Leading in turn to idolatry since people (wrongly) worship icons instead of God & the saints, thereby placing their faith in the wrong place
@MedievalND So one can't say the person is greater than the icon due to homonymy; this could allow people to "swap out" the individual for the icon.
@MedievalND Also on #TeamIconoclast, Nicephorus applied Ari's concepts of resemblance and homonymy; the resemblance of the icon to the person = homonymy
@MedievalND Conversely, if the icon is a bad icon, then worshipping it is worshipping an idol. #TeamIconoclast is not okay w/icons due to this logic.
@MedievalND 2nd Aristotelian concept: on consubstantiality. Constantine V argued: If an icon is good, it is consubstantial w/whom it is the icon of.
@MedievalND But these concepts of relative & co-relative was not 100% Aristotle's but belonged to later commentaries. Thus Byz scholars read widely.
@MedievalND One issue of debate Iconoclasts & Iconophiles tried to solve via Aristotle's ideas of relative & co-relative was: Is an icon an idol?
@MedievalND Fun historical nugget: 8th cent Byzantine scholars were already using Arabic texts to get to Aristotelian logic. :)
@MedievalND In the 8th century, one can see a shift away from Platonic thought to Aristotelian thought, a process Erismann calls "Aristotelianising".
@MedievalND Main questions: how was Aristotelian logic applied to the Iconoclast & Iconophile arguments & what this tell us about Byzantine education?

Time to change tactics. (And time for Historians to step away from the texts & start looking at what else is there.)
Correction: All of *our* knowledge and citations will not be enough to stop it.
And all my knowledge and citations will not be enough to stop it.
I can't laugh at people's ignorance because that ignorance is not harmless, it is not toothless, it is now powerless. It is anything but.
Especially since that idea has a profound level of public support & many public platforms in my country right now.
I don't know about you, but I'm more than a little sick to my stomach by the fact that the idea of a text can trump an actual text.
And all the evidence & citations in the world will not convince you otherwise because that's not your playing field.
But if you think what *you think about a text* is more important than what's in it, you will never accept a textual interpretation.
If you think that the text is more important, you will always turn to the text & try to find your proof within.
It all comes down to world view.
It's also how complete ignorance and deep textual criticism can exist at the same time & be in fierce competition with each other.
And that's how facts don't matter. That's how your opinion and your belief trumps (literally) fact and evidence.
You have your army and they will be on the attack against anyone & all who say otherwise.
And then, since you already gathered a following who believes what *you believe* about a text (even if empirically false) it doesn't matter.
"Fake News" as it were.
And if your own ignorance is pointed out, you can then accuse s.o. of "falsifying the evidence" or "interpreting it wrong."
Maybe the text is just a legitimizer, a symbol that you can point to in order to justify your actions while claiming authority.
But maybe the joke is on us.  Maybe you don't actually need the text, or rather, need to know what's in it to act on it.
But then we run into groups like #ISIS where the vast majority of its adherents are so profoundly ignorant of the basics we deride them.
This seems to be particularly true when talking about religious texts and, by extension, theology.
We think that when a text grabs people, they memorize its words, they understand its meaning & they recognize it when they see it.
I know we historians assume that a specific text can move the masses, but I think we don't really understand how. https://t.co/n7CSIBqIIZ

@MedievalND @KyotoU_News Thus "chai/Shay" (Persian/Arabic) vs "Tea/the/te" (English/French/Spanish).
@MedievalND @KyotoU_News "Cha" (Chinese) is the word associated tea traded overland (possibly via Tiberian middlemen) while "Te" (Chinese) signals southern maritime.
@MedievalND @KyotoU_News Even the word "Shay" ("tea") holds a clue about Central Asian & Islamic cultures, along w/the manner in which the good traveled.
@MedievalND @KyotoU_News Western Chinese & Central Asian archeology sites have so much to tell us about the movement of people, goods, & figural symbols.
@MedievalND @KyotoU_News But we only can see these places if we remove ourselves from the idea that "Islamic History" = only Middle East & Western Asia
@MedievalND @KyotoU_News However, moving into Chinese sources allows one to  understand Sino-Pahlavi sources plus Sino-Soghdian & Sino-Ctrl Asian relations.
@MedievalND @KyotoU_News Whole worlds are revealed by working in these languages, esp c. 800-1250 CE, b/c many Arabic & Persian sources are largely silent.
@MedievalND @KyotoU_News As a gen discipline, "Islamic Studies" gains so much by breaking out of the Asian-Persian binary & bringing in Chinese, Japanese & Russian.

Perhaps it should be obligatory for us to isolate the human factor of our temperament when it comes to solving the serious problems we face
So what can we do? In Morocco one says "don't thank me for what's obligatory" as a reply to thanks.
I mean, even Jesus tried to stop it from happening to him.
If it helps, imagine the other person harming or killing you for no good reason --or no reason at all.  You'd work to prevent that.
This Easter, think of ways that you can help others through means that don't rely upon appeals to goodness or human behavior.
Perhaps it's best if we realized that the only thing keeping us all from killing each other is our fickle mood & to design around that.
& therein lies the rub: we are only human & we only have each other to protect ourselves. We are all stuck in this planetary boat together.
So then: if we humans even killed a god who advocated love & mercy, where's the hope for the next guy? I'm not so sure I'd bet on humanity.
All that Easter brings to the believer is divine forgiveness of sin & entry into heaven in the next life, not an erasure of human nature.
Why is it that on Good Friday folks morn the Crucifixion but fail to see how Easter didn't turn us into infallible gods?
For all of the insistance on being "a Christian nation" why do we not see our flaw as a dangerous liability harming our ability to be just?
Why don't we have laws that prohibit discrimination & prohibit us from trying to circumnavigation said laws?
Why don't we have refugee & immigration policies that check our innate desire to harm? Why don't we have policies that check state violence?
So:  if 2 billion+ ppl believe in that flaw & acknowledge it as a fundamental part of the human condition, why don't we work around it?
And the Easter story hinges on that flaw as being beyond our control. It's the Original Sin upon which the whole sacrifice & salvation hangs
I am not a believer since I don't believe in a personal god, but Easter always makes me think about how *bad* we are at doing good to others
Or at least check that murderous tendency as best as humanly possible.
If we acknowledged that we are so utterly flawed that we even killed our own god, we'd make sure not to trust any system to our sympathies.
If we acknowledged depending upon "mercy" is utterly inadequate for solving systematic & persistant injustice, we might actually get peace.
If we recognized that "goodness" doesn't keep one from harming others, perhaps we'd have better protections in place to counter such reality
If we did acknowledge our ability to be cruel, to kill, & to treat our own kind as refuse, rubbish, & a threat, maybe we'd actually fix it.
As though the main issue with the Crucification was physically having blood on your hands, not the grusome killing by State & neighbor alike
Perhaps we shouldn't be so surprised by the casual way we inflict brutality on others & still "wash our hands" of it all in the end.
I know the Easter message is salvation & redemption but if that's how we treated a loving god, it sure says a lot about how we treat mortals
Today 2 billion+ morn the death of a god killed by his own creation. If that doesn't say s.th. dark about humanity, I don't know what does.

B/C that is the base definition of sex, other "types" of sex are those that mimick this penile/orifice penetrative relationship.
We *still* privilege penile penetration into an orifice (re: vagina) as *the* definition of sex. Case in point: technical virginity (in ♀️)
I suspect this has to do with gender privilege & with how we imagine rape--as s.th. done to s.o. with s.th (re: phallus)--than rape itself.
Moreover, when it comes to boys & men & girls & women and rape/sexual assault, it's only rape/assault for boys/men if the rapist is male.
And that those values privilege boys and men over girls and women, but not always in the same way.
To me, what this pearl clutching over Milo shows is that we have different values for men & women based on age & sexual acts.
And of course, noone is thinking about major/minor lesbian sex because 2 women don't have a sexuality, unless it's to "play lesbian" in porn
And then, it is more about homosexuality (re: butt sex! cause that's the only type pple think about) than  the fact that someone is a minor.
This leads me to conclude that that taboo of major/minor sex is only a strong taboo when it comes to homosexuality.
We see a similar lack of outrage when it comes to the various teacher-student relationships, even when those boys are as young as Milo likes
Chris Brown's "boast" about losing his virginity at 8 (that's called 'rape', BTW) is presented as "becoming a man" and "not a big deal."
Case in point : look at how our society talks about female-male sexual relationships when the man is underaged or even still a boy.
Had he been promoting heterosexual sex with an underaged male, he probably would still have a book deal.
The fact that Milo was promoting homosexual sex with an underaged partner also has something to do with it.
Folks are more upset that Weiner tweeted a picture of his chub with his son in the background than the fact that he sent it to a teen girl.
After all, when we hear about sexual activity w/a minor, we still think *well, some girls are like that.* Case in point: Anthony Weiner.
Perhaps this is cynicism, but seeing how nothing else stopped him until now, it's hard to imagine people caring about girls the same way.
Thread: If Milo had given the thumbs up to sex with underaged girls, I be he'd still have a book contract.
